February 15, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo in which you enclose correspondence regarding the admission of Peter Davey Johnson to the Lejac School. It is noted that you have already arranged to send this boy to the school and his admission is approved.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Harper Reed,
Indian Agent,
Telegraph Creek, B. C.
Towards the latter end of the month the case of Peter Johnson, age 6 - under Doctor's supervision over six months for sending to the Le Jack Industrial school to join his brother and sister there - was again taken up. Dr. Roth was now able to pass the child and therefore the necessary steps were taken to complete this desired end. Le Jack school was wired for acceptance, which was granted, and the necessary warrants and papers made out. A report on this school admittance case has also been submitted under separate cover. This action frees his father Davey Johnson, who since his wife died seems to have lost all energy to exist and was not capable of looking after his small and very decent son. Davey has now been told to get out of town and earn some revenue by trapping on this registered trap grounds and is granted no assistance.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

LEJAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

GENERAL REPORT
FOR QUARTER ENDING MARCH 31st., 1940.

ATTENDANCE.

We still have over 160 children in the school. This condition will probably continue until the end of the current school year. But, since we have been so far unsuccessful in obtaining an increase in pupilage, and have been deprived of three supernumerary pupils in reprisal for having tried to obtain an increase, we shall have to reduce the number of children next year.

It seems to us that the easiest way is to raise the entrance age from 7 years to 8. Thus, we will not accept any new pupils next fall, and thereby bring the number of children down to about 165.

MORALE.

The children seem to be quite happy and contented. So, far we have not had a single runaway this year. The only real trouble we have is with three children who were committed to my care by the Juvenile Court. I accepted them in order to save them the alternative of being sent to the Reformatory.

HEALTH.

We have been singularly fortunate in this regard, and have had very little sickness of any kind. One girl had to be sent to Kamloops for eye treatment, one boy broke his leg, and another had an infected hand.

There is now a doctor at Fraser Lake who acts as Medical Officer for the School. We have not had an emergency for him as yet; but I must confess that I am not particularly impressed by him, and have not a great deal of confidence in him.

LIVESTOCK.

The farm animals are all doing well, and we look forward to a substantial increase in the number of cattle and sheep this spring. We have now about 60 pigs in the new piggery. Due to a small fire we lost about 250 hens by suffocation. This loss was mitigated by the fact that they were the oldest birds and the decrease in egg prices.

CROPS.

Preparations are already being made for the coming season. Most of the seed is already in hand; and there are about 10 acres more of newly broken land to be brought into cultivation this spring.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter above indicated, I wish to say that I intend to keep the girl, Mabel Bramford, #0136, in school for a further two years as is provided for in the Indian Act, sect.10, art.1; with the consent of the General Superintendent, which I hope can be obtained by your recommendation.

This girl is an orphan, and has absolutely no place to go if she leaves school. Her sister is an undesirable character, and her Brother does not want her. So, in my estimation, it is for the best interest of this girl that she remain in school, until I can find a suitable place for her.

As regards the twenty-one days' grant deducted from Stephen Jael. I did not deduct this period, as I usually do, because of the fact that I have 164 pupils, and am only receiving the grant for 160, I thought that it did not make any appreciable difference. Therefore, I was not asking for the per capita grant for this boy for the time that he was in the hospital, since it does not affect the average attendance in point of view of the grant.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I would like to have Mary Magdalene Pierre, age 11 years and Bertha, age 9 years, orphans of the Fort Grahame Band admitted to the Lejac Indian Residential School. These orphans now reside with Isadore Joe North at Tekla Landing Indian Reserve. I visited this family recently and would report the home is indescribably filthy and positively unfit for youngsters to live in. Miss Finan the teacher at Tekla Landing Seasonal School states the girls are quite bright and anxious to go to the Residential School and get away from their present surroundings.

The Rev. Principal has a full quota of pupils for the coming school year, but he is willing to accept the two girls providing they can be admitted as supernumerary covered by grant and their transportation paid from Takla Landing to Vanderhoof. Transportation costs would amount to approximately $12.00 each. Both girls have been medically examined; Bertha has a huge goitre which should be attended to otherwise their health is satisfactory.

I am convinced the best place for these orphans is in the Residential School and would recommend, if possible, that the school grant be increased to cover maintenance and the expenditure authorised for their transportation to school.

Yours truly,

Robert Howe,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to two orphan children of the Fort Graham Band whom you consider require institutional care.

Owing to the reduction in our Appropriation for tuition grants, it is not possible to allow payment for supernumeraries during the current fiscal year. The two children whom you mention appear to be very deserving cases and it is felt that the Principal of the Lejac School should make some arrangements to accept them even though supernumerary grant is not allowed. It is quite possible that there are a number of children in the school who could be discharged and in this manner vacancies would be created for those actually in need.

AGENT'S REPORT ON STUART LAKE AGENCY FOR SEPTEMBER

LEJAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

School commenced on the 3rd instant. The Rev. Principal reported 54 absentees on the 16th; an unusually large number. I regret that it was necessary to call Corpl. Fielder of the local Detachment of R.C.M.P. Police to round up the truants. To date 25 truants have been returned to school and it is expected the remainder will be in school shortly. The Indians offer a number of excuses for failing to return their children to school, but I think the chief reason is that the Principal inadvertently and unbeknown to this office advertised through the missionaries that the pupilage would be reduced from 200 last year to 150 for this year.

The Department under letter No. Cir-502-1000 May 22nd, 1940 advised that a reduction in the School Grant was necessary and that there would be no objections to reducing the pupilage to conform with the grant.

I feel sure the Indians took advantage of this statement as an excuse to keep their children at home. It would have been better policy to keep silent about the reduction until after the opening of school and then weeded out a number to conform with the pupilage desired.

Robt. Howe,
Indian Agent.
At the request of the local Ind.Agent R. Howe, Esq., I patrolled to the a/m points for the purpose of checking Indian Absentee School Children, arranging for their transportation to Lejac School and other matters pertaining to his branch of service.

On Sunday, Sept. 22nd, 1940, driving Pol.Car. Code #2543, I left Vanderhoof and patrolled to Stoney Creek & Laketown Ind.Reserves, collected three children and drove them to Lejac Ind.School returning to Vanderhoof at 9 P.m., on the same day.

On Sept. 23rd, I travelled to Ft. St.James per Pol.Car and continued through to Tachie and Portage Reserves located at the north end of Stewart Lake, B.C. The patrol up the Lake was made by Ind.Dept.launch with Mr.G. Hamilton hired as Pilot and Guide. Sept. 23rd to Sept. 25th, was spent at Tachie and Portage Ind.Reserves interviewing parents of absentee children and making arrangements for the transportation.

Gasoline and Motor Oil issues were made to parents bringing their children to Ft. St.James and on the morning of Sept. 26th, I left Tachie together with (5) Indian motor boats bringing (10) school children from Tachie (5) from Portage and (4) from Trembleur Lake. Without untoward incident we all arrived at the Ft. at 11 A.m., the same day. I remained with the Children until 5.30 P.m. and turned them over to Father Simpson, O.M.I., on his arrival there with the necessary transport for the children to be taken to Lejac. Following this procedure I returned to Vanderhoof arriving at 8 P.m.

Including three children collected at Ft. St.James Reserve a total of (25) have been returned to School today.

It is evident among these northern Indians that they care little or nothing about sending their children to school for several reasons verbally outlined by me to the local Ind.Agent who in turn has transmitted them to the Priest Father Simpson who holds the position of Principal at Lejac Indian School.

Free transportation by boat was obtained. No crime was encountered during this patrol or Complaints of serious nature received. Copy of this report handed to the local Ind.Agent together with a list of Gasoline & Motor Oil issues to Indians, and a list of Twine and clothing issues to Indians.

Expenses shown on Fm 93, Period Sept.15/30th, 1940.

Cpl.
L.F.Fielder, Reg.#9521.

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending December 31st., 1940.

ATTENDANCE.
The return of a considerable number of children at the beginning of the quarter brought up the number of the children to well over the number allowed for in the per capita grant. We expect to receive a few more destitute children at the beginning of the new year.

Morale.
All of the children are in very good spirits, and very little trouble has been experienced with them. So far, there has not been a single attempt to run away from school; every one of the children seems to be quite satisfied.

MANUAL TRAINING.
This is proceeding along the customary lines; carpentry and farm instruction for the boys; and the usual household work for the girls, combined with instruction in spinning, carding, rug-making, dressmaking, and the making up of articles for the Red Cross.

HEALTH.
The general health of the children is very good, and very few have had to stay in bed at all this quarter. The exceptions are four or five who have been suffering with acute tonsillitis; we are waiting for the doctor to make arrangements to have tonsillectomies performed on several of the children.

Livestock.
All of the animals are in good shape, and the numbers remain about the same. Our herd of Holstein cattle is consistently maintaining the best record in the district for the production of butter fat and poundage of milk.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Barry:

Will you kindly give us a ruling on the following question, and thereby clear up another of our difficulties with Indian Agent Mallinson?

When new children wish to enter the school, they are brought here by the principal or his agents. Upon arrival here they are examined by the school doctor, the "Application for Admission" forms are filled out, sent back to the camp for the parents' signature, and then these forms are sent to the Indian agent concerned for his signature and forwarding to Ottawa.

Such is the modus operandi used here for the admission of new pupils; and, I believe, in other schools as well. If the medical examination had to be carried out in the camps, sometimes months would elapse before the child could see the doctor, or vice versa. Of course, if the doctor finds a child unfit for entry to the school, that child is immediately sent home. Is this practice in any way contrary to the rules or wishes of the Indian Department?

My reason for asking is that there are two children living in undesirable conditions near Telkwa, whom Father Godfrey has been trying to send to this school for nearly three months. He has been unable to do so because Mr. Mallinson insists that they cannot be sent here until the necessary forms are filled out and authorization is received from Ottawa. These children are still waiting for their medical examination. The agent will not allow them to come here to be examined by the school doctor, as explained above.

Please let me have your opinion on this question as soon as is convenient; and I would appreciate it if you will advise Mr. Mallinson accordingly.

Yours truly,

"Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, C.M.I."

March 25th, 1941.

Sir,

I beg to submit, hereunder, a Report, covering the activities of this Agency over the month of February 1941.

A winter visit to the Atlin end of the Agency had been in mind for some time, therefore clearing up the Office detail work as much as possible, the Office was turned over to Dr Meyer to carry on with, and the Mail Plane of the 15th inst was taken on its return to Atlin.

Here it was discovered that nearly all the local Indians were in Town, with also their dogs. It seemed that no trapping of any amount had been undertaken during the winter, up to the present time; and little fur, if any had been obtained and sold. Going into the reason why this had come about, the information was allowed that The Bishop was coming and a lot of Fathers also, and big meetings were to be held. This state of affairs is not quite as bad as it sounds, for the fur obtainable around the mining camp of Atlin, is really of no great account, and if the Indians consistently trap their grounds, they would become depleted in a couple of years. However, as Bishop Condelet, O.M.I., was in Residence at the R.C. Mission Church, he was at once called upon. It was found that a meeting of all the R.C. Fathers was taking place, and the gathering numbered 6 in all. Here was a very good chance to talk over all Mission Affairs, with His Lordship; with the various Fathers concerned present. Therefore on the 16th inst a meeting was held, and all matters of all sorts were gone into, especially those concerning the various Mission Schools. A request was received from His Lordship to have two Atlin children sent to the Lejack Mission Industrial School, and therefore that routine was taken up, Ottawa's permission obtained and the arrangements carried out to enable the Bishop to take these children with him, upon his return to Atch. Much of the detail regarding this meeting will be contained in the school reports made about to be rendered, but His Lordship was good enough to admit that he had learned much in the 5½ hours we expanded in talking about Mission and Indian affairs; than he had learnt during the time he had been mixed up with the Stikine agency, up to then. It was possible, however to have Father Dream, O.M.I., who went into Teslin Lake and opened up a R.C. Mission Church at that point, in direct opposition to the already established English Church Mission, there; to mark on the Office Census Sheet the Indians who as at to-day he claims belong to the R.C. Mission Church. It now appears that he owns over half the Indian Band, but of course this matter will be taken up with the Indians themselves, when Inspector Coleman is present.

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending March 31st., 1941.

ATTENDANCE.
Several children have been admitted during the quarter, and at present we have 159 children actually in the school.

MORALE.
No complaint can be made about the behaviour of the children. They all seem quite happy and contented to be at school. There have been no runaways this quarter again.

MANUAL TRAINING.
This is proceeding along the customary lines. The girls are doing more work for the Red Cross, in knitting and sewing.

HEALTH.
On the whole the general health has been good. Cases of influenza were rather numerous for a while, but none of them were serious. Two children were sent to the hospital, one with acute mastoiditis, the other with T.B.

Dr. Holmes was here March 24th. and 25th., during which time he performed tonsillectomies on 32 children. Every operation was completely successful, and there was not a single case of bleeding. Dr. Holmes is worthy of commendation for his excellent work.

LIVESTOCK.
All of the animals are in good shape, and we have about the same number of all stock, except pigs and chickens, whose numbers are somewhat less.

IMPROVEMENTS.
The ammonia refrigerating plant has been discarded, and an ice system has been installed in its place. This ice system is now in operation, and seems to be quite satisfactory.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Sir,

Re:- Indian Lad "George" U.S.A. Born. Discharge from LEJACK School.

I beg to once again submit for your consideration the above case of an illegitimate lad born in Juneau S.E. Alaska, smuggled into B.C. by way of the Taku River; and later, with the aid of Rev Father Allard, O.M.I., then in Atlin B.C., was sent to the R.C. School at Lejack B.C. Altho much correspondance has passed regarding this case, the lad has remained there ever since and is now ready for discharge.

No doubt but what Mrs Telegraph-Jack, full indian of Atlin, allowed her daughter Bessie, now deceased some years, to obtain an illegitimate child whilst staying for a visit in Juneau. Bessie stayed on there, and the child was taken care of by some relatives. Some years later Mrs Telegraph-Jack again visited Juneau, and as she and her husband were getting along in life, with their only son married, they returned to Canada with their illegitimate grandson. Smuggling this boy in, they obtained assistance from Rev Father Allard, and he without taking the correct routine, sent this lad to Lejack School.

The Telegraph-Jack family are rather well off, and rather ignore the aid of the Indian Department. They consider that whatever the R.C. Mission states is correct, and it is only necessary to fix matters with them. They are given to obtaining intoxicants whenever possible, which is nothing more than other indians do, but on account of their well-fixed condition, can do so more often.

Their son Willie Jack has just been granted the privilege of sending two of his children to the Lejack School, and this family were rather annoyed that the fares involved, were not paid by the Department. This they can well afford to do as was proven to Bishop Courdet, O.M.I., recently.

His Lordship, a week or so ago, requested that the Department consider this case again, and as the lad has received training at the Canadian School, and is reported as "good" that he be accepted into the Atlin Band of Indians, and returned to the care of Mrs Telegraph-Jack.

Taken from a broad point of view, it would seem the only action to take, but in all these half-breed cases, further troubles will come about as the lad grows up. In any case the Telegraph-Jack Family should pay all costs concerned. May further instructions in this matter be received, please.

Dear Sir:

Re: Francis Isadore.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant following our previous conversation concerning the above named Indian boy presently attending the school at Lejac.

In my opinion the home environment in this particular case is such that it will be extremely beneficial to have the boy remain in the school under control of the school authorities just as long as is possible. Both the father and the mother are trouble-makers and an older sister, Josephine, is sub-normal with a very particular inclination towards vagrancy and everything that goes with it. I understand that she is at present under the Doctor's care for a venereal complaint and that there is difficulty in keeping her to the treatments.

If it can be arranged to have this boy remain in the residential school at Lejac for a further period I recommend unhesitatingly that this be done for I am convinced that the more schooling that he can get under the supervision of the school authorities the better will be his chances of becoming self-supporting and self-respecting after he finishes school.

Yours faithfully,

H.B. Campbell

Sir:
I beg to submit herewith General Report for September 1941.

Lejac Residential School reopened on September 27th. Fifty absentees were reported. Constables Rae and Sharpe rounded up most of these and at the time of writing 157 pupils are in attendance; several more than covered by the grant.

Doctor McQuarrie arrived at Vanderhoof on the 30th, and arrangements were made for T.B. tests and X-ray for a number of Indians as well as pupils at Lejac Residential School.

LEJAC INDIAN
RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending September 30th., 1941.

ATTENDANCE.
Very little difficulty was experienced this year in bringing the children back to school, and it did not take long before we had more children than the "per capita grant" allows for. In this respect, the cordial assistance of Mr. Howe, and the other officials of the Stuart Lake Agency, was of great value, and is greatly appreciated.

MORALE.
The children are in good spirits, and seem to be very glad to be back in school, with very few exceptions.

MANUAL TRAINING.
This is already in full swing for both boys and girls. A good number of the boys are gaining valuable knowledge and experience in the reconstruction of the chicken house, to which is being added a second floor.

HEALTH.
Quite a number of the children have had very bad colds, and several developed pneumonia, two had to be taken to the hospital for treatment. This epidemic now seems to have petered out. We have been greatly handicapped by the fact that the medical supplies which were requisitioned for last April, have not yet arrived; and our stocks of several essential articles are completely exhausted. At present we are awaiting the arrival of Dr. MacQuarrie, who is bringing an X-ray apparatus, and will hold a T.B. clinic here at the school.

CROPS.
While the yield was excellent this year, it is to be feared that there will be a considerable loss in the harvesting. Since the 24th. of August, we have had rain every day, which has prevented the threshing of the grain, and the bringing in of the hay crop. It is too soon yet to say how much of the crop will have to be considered as lost.

LIVESTOCK.
We are still keeping about the same number of animals of all kinds, and disposing of the increase. The stock are in very good condition, and the lamb and pig crops have been disposed of at satisfactory prices.

COST OF LIVING.
The cost of living index has sharply risen for us, as well as for all others. Many of the staple lines of food and clothing are greatly increased in price; and it is becoming more and more difficult for us to meet expenses with our present income. The government has acknowledged that its civil servants are entitled to a "cost of living bonus," and it would seem only just the Indians, the wards of the Government, are entitled to equal consideration. I hope that this will be considered by the Department of Indian Affairs; and that ways and means can be found to increase the "per capita" allowance in proportion to the cost of living.

We have applied to the Provincial Government for permission to purchase moose meat from the Indians, in view of the high cost of beef; but we are not very hopeful of receiving a favourable reply.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Doris Tom, age 5,
Margaret Tom, age 2,

Dear Mr. Howe:

Acting with your approval, I have received these three children into the school. As you are aware, their mother died last year, and the father, Mean Baptiste Tom, is so badly crippled with arthritis as to be incapable of working and providing for their support.

The eldest one, Jessie, is old enough to take her place with the rest of the school children; but the two younger ones give us quite a lot of extra work and care. Accordingly, I would appreciate it greatly if the Department of Indian Affairs would provide for Doris and Margaret as supernumerary pupils. This would be of considerable assistance for us, especially in view of the fact that we have already several children in excess of the number provided for in our "per capita grant."

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

I hereby request that the Department of Indian Affairs allow this girl to remain in school until she reaches the age of eighteen years.

Mabel Storrit is an orphan, and has no one to exercise proper care and supervision over her physical and moral welfare should she have to leave school. Although she has been on the rolls since 1931, she was out of school for four years, from 1934 to 1938, taking care of her grandmother, after whose death she came back to school.

Mabel has a very good record in school, and, in my opinion, is a deserving girl, and capable of absorbing further instruction at this school.

Dear Sir,

May I ask advice of you Sir, regarding this case that has made it very difficult for me, because we refused the Indian Agent in sending my brother Edgar Williams back to school, because he felt that it best for me to let him attend School here at Glen Fawell and has progressed here very much as a pupil under Major Parkinson, the teacher and the only difficulty is that my brother was baptized a Catholic and the objects very much to return to Lefse for its more of a prison to him than a school. I know how my brother feels because I was there for seven terms and I was not able to speak English very well until I attended the white school at Woodstock for one and a half term, while there I progressed a lot. I will now present the story in full.
In the year 1934, my mother and Dad separated because he was beating my mother several times which I believe got her ill and finally died as a result from the severe beating she received. In the first place they were not legally married while we were with Auntie Mrs J Shettle at Woodcock. My mother wrote to Alex Williams my Dad asking for support but he refused flatly to contribute to my brother's support. Auntie Shettle bought all the clothes for my brother for some time and I was attending school at Lepic at the time. This was the year I believe that my brothers started school along with the Shettle. We were all in grade 1 in 1935. My mother had to send them to Lepic because she was unable to support my brothers two years rolled by and in the spring of 1937 June 8th I receive a telegram from mother and we returned to her call at once. She was on her dying bed then she spoke to my auntie Mrs Henry Russell and said "Sister you look after my children from now on because my eldest sister Mrs J Shettle..."
has too many of her own; now I must
leave you all. "Farewell," these were
her last words. My brothers returned
to Lepic after their summer vacation,
and I was discharged at sixteen years
of age. Four years went by and I knew
that my brothers, to my surprise, they
were not able to read or do their school
work as any average pupil should do.
This is five terms for them at Lepic
and they are only in Grade IV. And as
I mentioned in the letter they started
the same time as the Thistle's and
had the same opportunity today.
Lawrence and Charlotte Thistle are ready
for promotion into Grade VIII there
must be something wrong somewhere.
This is why we kept him back because
he is certainly not learning anything
else. He was comparing with any
average pupil like at Glen Howell.
I was at Lepic when the four children
ran away from Lepic sometime at New
Year's and were found froze to death.
Just a quarter of a mile from Fort
Fraser after a thirteen mile journey
through a blizzard, so you naturally
will know that the children are not.
very happy to a certain extent.

Today Alex Williams is making a lot of fuss because we are living here with auntie Russell at Glen Howell and by the way, auntie Russell gave him a chance to have his own son Edgar to spend his vacation with him at Moncton for about two or three weeks. I was also helping him put up his hay crop at his ranch and during my absence my stepmother was treating my little brother very mean indeed and on my return to their house my brother Edgar told me about it.

He says he can't get his breakfast until noon sometimes because he has to do his chores first and often he had to beg for some bread from the neighbors around who also told me about it.

This is what greeted me very much some for Glen Howell with auntie Russell.

The Indian Agent is demanding my brother's return to Lejac which we object very much but he says, that in his personal feeling that this home of the Russells is certainly very clean and that my brother Edgar is very healthy and happy and everything the child's
wishes to have he is really at home and we are very fond of him. But the state's it is according to the Indian act that no Catholic should reside or attend school on Salvation Army Reserve. So I pointed out to him that this has not being observed because I know a number of Catholics attending Anglican school at Sagerton that is Mrs Edith Birde children and also Johnson Alexander children are attending the Keapio school and going to church on a United Church Reserve so I feel that my brother has equal rights to those of other Catholics on different Reserve I also don't see why one child should observe the Indian act while others are free. And the only objections is that my brother is a Catholic. My auntie Mrs Henry Russell wants to adopt Edgar because auntie Thistle is adopting his brother Robert but Mr Mallinson says Alex Williams will not give his consent. I would not trouble you about this but Mr Mallinson our Indian Agent told me he was writing Ottawa so I feel we must let you know why we have refused our Indian Agent.

(To be continued)
I certainly would appreciate any assistance or advice you forward us and hoping you will reply promptly on this matter.

I remain,
Harold P. Williams.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that it is necessary to transfer two boys, Donald Baker and Philip Roy to the Lejac Indian Residential School. Donald Baker is at present an inmate of St. John's School which is conducted under the auspices of the Catholic Children's Aid Society in Vancouver, but is being transferred within the next day or two. The other boy, Philip Roy, has been a patient in the Sardis Indian Hospital and has recovered sufficiently to return to the school.

The usual procedure in the case of the transfer of such young people is to send them by rail under the care of an escort, in which case their transportation would cost $17.62 each plus meals and the return fare of an escort from Vancouver would cost $62.75 plus berth for four nights, meals and a stopover at Lejac awaiting return train; however, these boys can be sent by Air Plane from Vancouver to Prince George at a cost of $16.50 each, and as the trip lasts only about two hours, escort, berth and meals are not required. On arrival at Prince George they could be met by Mr. Indian Agent Howe or his Constable and transferred to Lejac by Agency car.

In view of the very considerable saving by use of the Air Plane transportation I would recommend same and request your authority by Air Mail for provision of the Air Plane passage.

Yours faithfully,

Tahltan Indian Reserve No. 7

The Indians of this Reserve are all Catholics and the children do not attend any school while there during the summer. They arrive about the end of April and leave for their trapping grounds when snow falls about the end of October.

Arrangements are being made to send four or five of the children to Lejac Indian Residential School, where home conditions are unsatisfactory. There are several more children here that should be sent, these being two block families the mothers having died during the past year and left behind quite large and young families. One of these were quite neglected during my visit, the father being absent on river work. The young woman in charge was told to look after them properly.

These children receive a little instruction during the winter at the Klappan bush School, but it is not considered that this is very satisfactory.

ATTENDANCE:
The attendance has remained constant throughout the quarter, although several children lost a few days as patients in the hospital. Three new children were admitted at the beginning of the quarter.

MORALE:
This continues excellent; there was no serious trouble with any of the children, nor were there any runaways.

MANUAL TRAINING:
The boys have done good work in the carpenter shop, the blacksmith shop, in painting and repairing several of the farm and school buildings, and in the construction of a small greenhouse.
The girls have been very industrious in knitting and sewing for the Red Cross, as well as for the needs of the house.

HEALTH:
Quite a number of the children had mild attacks of the "flu," and a few had to be sent to the hospital for various reasons. However, there were no deaths among the children although one girl was very seriously ill with a blood condition.

CROPS:
Despite the prevailing shortage of farm labour, we have been fortunate in maintaining a sufficient force of staff for the needs of the farm. All of the seeding was done in good time, and thanks to the generous rains, the prospects for a good crop are very bright.

Livestock:
The crop of lambs and calves has been fairly good. All of the livestock are in good condition, and are doing very well now that there is green pastures available for them.

New Building:
A small greenhouse has been built on the foundations of a building that had been destroyed some years ago. This addition to our buildings has already proved its worth in forcing the plants for transplanting to the vegetable garden.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Under date of March 30th., 1941, you wrote to me concerning an account submitted to the Department by the R.C.M.P. for expenses incurred in bringing children back to the school after the summer vacation. For some reason I took offence from your letter and, without sufficient reflection, sent back a reply which, I fear, you must have found insulting, to say the least.

Afterwards, I realised that your letter was merely a routine one in the interest of keeping down unnecessary expenses and entirely impersonal. Consequently I deeply regretted my hasty action in replying to you as I did, and have many times intended to apologise to you for any offence that I may have caused you.

re- Applications for Admission to Lejac Residential School.

I enclose herewith applications for the admission of Arthur and Mabel Tom to the Lejac Indian Residential School.

These two children are the illegitimate children of Mary Tom, Indian of the Tsitsik Band, but, although their mother is alive she has never cared for them, and they have for the past number of years lived with a relative of theirs named Selina Francis who has acted as their guardian. This woman is not in very good health and is not able to keep the children clean or look after them properly, and I consider that for the children's own good they should be sent to a residential school.

I have not been able to discuss this matter with their guardian, Selina Francis, she being away at present, but I am of the opinion that she will not give her consent to their being sent away to school. Re: Selina Francis, (Indian Woman),
Tsitsik Indian Reserve,
Section 10 (4) Indian Act.

1. With reference to the above, on the 11th instant, S. Wallington, Esq., Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C., called at this office and stated that he was having difficulty with the above named in having her second child in her charge, Arthur and Mabel Tom, to the Lejac Indian Residential School, and he requested that the following letter be delivered to her by a member of this detachment:

BEGINS:
Habine Agency
Hazelton, B.C.
Sept. 4, 1942.

Head Madam,

re- Arthur and Mabel Tom.

I wish to advise that the Department, Ottawa, have agreed to the admission of Arthur and Mabel Tom to the Lejac Indian School.

Please take notice that this order must be carried out, and I would ask you to have them ready to leave in three or more days time. Kindly have them ready to leave on the night of September 14-15, Monday Night.

Yours truly,
(Sgd) S. Wallington
Indian Agent.

Selina Francis,
Tsitsik Reserve.

ENDS.

2. At 3:30 p.m., of the 21st instant, at the above named's home on the Tsitsik Indian Reserve, I delivered and explained the contents of the above quoted letter, and also warned her verbally, as a truant officer, to see that these children were sent to school as instructed, otherwise, she would be subject to prosecution under the Indian Act.

3. On the 16th inst., the Indian Agent, again called at this office and produced a letter he had received from Selina Francis, wherein she stated that she absolutely refused to send these children to school.

As it is quite evident that these children will not be sent to school without a prosecution, I informed the Agent that an Information and Complaint was being laid before H.B. Campbell, Stipendiary Magistrate, Smithers, B.C., and he, The Indian Agent, requested that the case be held in abeyance until he takes the matter up with the Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

4. In view of the Indian Agent's request no further action is being taken in this connection, until a further request is received from the Agent. Please set D.D.D., for report to end 15-10-42.

SIGN: NO EXPENSE INCURRED.

Rev. A.R. Simpson, Principal, Lejac Indian Residential School was absent for ten days during the month obtaining medical treatment at Vancouver.

Mr. R. Howe, Indian Agent, Vanderhoof, B.C.

I am in receipt of a report from the R.C.M.P. with reference to Albert Prince and Mac Patrick, truant pupils of the Lejac Residential School. It is noted that these boys were brought back from Prince Rupert although they were employed at that point and are stated to be at least 14 years of age. From the information at our disposal it is difficult for us to understand why such heavy expense should have been incurred. You are aware, of course, that the expenses of the R.C.M.P. in returning truant pupils to a residential school are all paid by this Branch. From our point of view the boys had been located, were working and are probably older than 14. Besides, we understand that the Lejac School has its full quota of pupils. With these things in mind you can easily understand why we were surprised that instructions were apparently issued from your office to have the boys returned immediately to the Lejac School without consulting the Department. Your explanation would be appreciated.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to the above mentioned truants of the Lejac Indian Residential School. These boys ran away from Lejac Nov. 10th 1942 and were located at Prince Rupert by the Prince Rupert Detachment of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Constable Rae of the Agency Staff escorted them to Lejac.

The truants were returned to school at the urgent request of the Principal. I was reluctant to bring them back especially when they were employed at the Shipyards, an important war industry. However, it was necessary to take into consideration the effect on the other pupils at the School. If these truants had been allowed to remain away we would have had an epidemic of runaways. Three others ran away a few days after the truants in question but were located shortly after. The fact that these truants were brought back to School had a deterring effect on others contemplating truancy.

Having in mind the tragedy which occurred a few years ago when several pupils lost their lives running away from Lejac School during sub-zero weather, I think the action taken was the wisest course to follow in order to prevent a possible repetition.

The only expense the Mounted Police may have incurred in the case is the cost of one telegram and three or four meals for the truants.

Mr. R.H.S. Sampson, Indian Agent, Telegraph Creek, B.C.

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo, with reference to certain children on the Tahltan Reserve who you feel should be placed in the Lejac Residential School.

The Department has always felt that it is very important to have a very careful medical examination of children before placing them in a residential school. The suggestion contained in the second-last paragraph of your letter might be difficult to carry out, because, if the children were examined and found to have tuberculosis, it might not be possible at that time to place them in the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital and, therefore, they would have to remain in the Lejac School where their condition might be a menace to the health of the other pupils.

Taking everything into consideration the Department feels that no action should be taken in this matter at the present time, but we would appreciate hearing from you again about the first of July at which time the matter will receive further consideration with a view to determining if we can arrange for their examination before going to the school and, if so, those physically fit could be sent for the 1943-44 term.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
There are about twelve children between the ages of six and eleven who have lost their mothers in recent years and are now a considerable burden upon their fathers, Indians of Tahltan Band. These children are of Roman Catholic faith and the Principal of the Lejac School is urging that they be admitted to the school. Bishop Coudert, who was interviewed recently, also thinks the children should be sent to Lejac.

As the Department is aware, there is no doctor here now and therefore a thorough physical examination cannot be obtained by the children before going to the school. In view of the fact that there is considerable tuberculosis amongst these Indian families it seems all the more desirable to have a thorough examination of all children who are to be admitted to residential school.

Bishop Coudert has suggested that it might be possible to have the children examined when they arrived at Lejac and if active disease was found in any of them, that they be sent on to the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital at Sardis.

I should be pleased to have the Department's views in this matter as it would be of great benefit to the children and fathers of the aforementioned families if the children could be admitted to residential school.

Indian Agent.

LEJAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

GENERAL REPORT

For quarter ending March 31st., 1943.

ATTENDANCE

Our attendance remains about the same, although we have sent three more children to the hospital for T.B. treatment; two absentees returned, and there were two new admissions.

MORALE

The children are all in good spirits, and give very little serious trouble. There have been no truants during the past quarter, due, no doubt, to the fact that the boys who ran away in November were speedily brought back to the school.

MANUAL TRAINING

The boys are doing rather well in the carpentry work, they have rebuilt part of the chicken-house which burned down, they have made a number of useful articles of furniture, and several repairs to the buildings. Due to the scarcity of the inferior quality of rubber boots, they are obliged to fall back on the use of leather boots once more. This necessitates a shoe repair shop, which has been set up, with a competent instructor for the boys.

The girls continue with their work in making clothes, mending and knitting, embroidery, etc., as well as with the arts of the kitchen.

HEALTH

The children have had a very hard time this winter. Following the whooping cough of last quarter, we had the chicken-pox, then the flu, and now we have the measles. Two weeks ago there were 69 children in bed at the same time. Fortunately, there have been no deaths to report. One boy broke his leg while skiing, but he is all right now.

LIVESTOCK

The stock have come through the winter in fairly good condition, and we have not lost any. The only misfortune we had was with the lambs, many of which were born too soon, and twelve of them froze to death in the extreme temperatures, 40 below zero. We have restored about half of the chicken-house which burned down in November last.

IMPROVEMENTS

We have arranged to have the programmes of the National Film Board shown here at the school. The children study the subject matter of the films beforehand, from the booklets which are provided, and they seem to take an intelligent interest in the films. A Victor Sound Projector, 10mm., has also been added to the school equipment, from which the children derive a great deal of benefit and amusement.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Medical Report on the Progress of
Theresa Abraham, age 18, Bear Lake Band.

This Indian girl was sick for 9 months in the hospital, with Infantile Paralysis, and came to the Lejac Indian Residential School in August of 1942.

On admission to the school, Theresa was unable to walk as the results of the Paralysis, without the aid of (2) crutches. Also, her eyes were extremely weak and infected.

Now she can walk fairly well without any assistance, however the right lower extremity is still very weak, and she depends on the wall for support.

It will be some time before Theresa is able to return home. She is a bright girl and seems one who will reap the full benefits of the school, and she is happy and contented here.

Dear Sir:

Re Theresa Abraham, age 18, 0424.

In view of what you said in your letter of October 14th., 1942 (file #163-1-10) concerning the special circumstances under which this girl was admitted to this school, I was considerably surprised to receive a peremptory demand for her discharge at the end of the current school year, which was transmitted to me from your office by Mr. Indian Agent Howe.

In the above mentioned letter of last October, you asked that a report be submitted to you concerning this girl before the end of June 1943, at which time the question of her remaining in the school for another year would be given consideration by you. I am enclosing herewith the report of the School Medical Officer on the case; and I beg to submit also my own opinion, as follows.

Theresa Abraham, although already 18 years old, has had no previous opportunity to attend school, and, at the time of her admission here, was completely illiterate. During the months that she has been able to attend classes, she has worked hard and well, and has made satisfactory progress. She is very anxious to learn, at least, to read and write.

Realising how remote her home at Bear Lake is from all medical attention, she has begged that she be allowed to remain at this school until she has completely recovered from the effects of the attack of infantile paralysis which she suffered more than a year ago.

Therefore, in view of the above circumstances, and of the opinion given in the medical report, I strongly recommend that Theresa Abraham be permitted to remain in the Lejac Indian Residential School for at least another year.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

AIR MAIL

Mr. R. Howe, Indian Agent, Vanderhoof, B.C.

The section of your telegram of July 22 which refers to placing children from Fort Grahame in the Lejac Residential School has been referred to me.

As the Welfare Division has authorized the necessary food for those requiring same and as the summer holiday period is now in effect at the Lejac School, it was felt that you should be written before authorizing any specific action.

As you know, the authorized pupilage at the Lejac School is 160, but grant is allowed for only 92.24% of this number, or 147.58. Under these circumstances you should confer with the Principal of the Lejac School and ascertain how many children from Fort Grahame he can take, as present regulations do not permit our paying supernumerary grant over the number of 147.58. It should also be understood that the Department only favours placing in the Lejac School children who have reached the age of 7 years. Children younger than this age should be placed with friends or relatives at Fort Grahame, even though you have to apply later for authority for food for them. Similar action should be taken with reference to children of 14 or 15 years of age. This is the only provision that can be made, unless the Lejac School is able to accommodate them within the number of grant-earning pupils and, in view of the large enrolment at this school in the past, it is considered advisable to obtain full particulars before making a decision.

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending September 30th., 1943.

ATTENDANCE
At the time of writing this report there are 145 children in school. We had anticipated some difficulty in reaching our quota this year due to prevailing economic conditions, but it did not materialize. However, though the boys are numerous, there are no really big boys, which is quite a handicap tous in our farming operations.

All during the summer vacation we had about 25 children in school; which is an expense, as far as I am aware, that other Residential Schools do not have.

MORALE
Despite the fact that there was considerable reluctance on the part of the parents to send their children back to school, the children themselves are in high spirits and seem to be quite content to be back in school, with perhaps two exceptions.

Health
Many of the children on their return were lousy, there was a great deal of impetigo, itch, etc. We now have this well in hand. At the moment a slight epidemic of the "flu" is going through the school.

MANUAL TRAINING
A number of the boys are already at work helping to rebuild the chicken house which burned down last winter; the shoe shop is in operation, and the various chores of the farm.

The girls are also back in their usual routine of domestic economy, knitting, dressmaking, repairing and renewing clothing, etc.

LIVESTOCK
The stock have done well this summer. We are now preparing to send over 50 head of cattle and about 50 head of sheep to the market.

CROPS
On the whole, the crops are far below the yield of last year, and the harvesting operations are considerably later. But, if the weather permits, we ought to get enough feed grains to see us through the winter. We probably have enough hay put up, although there is a local shortage of feed.

SUPPLIES
The problem of obtaining clothing and food supplies is becoming more acute. This will be somewhat alleviated for us by the fact that during the summer we put up nearly 2000 quarts of fruit and vegetable tables; a great proportion of which was wild fruit.

PROPERTY
During the summer the necessary repairs were made to the water tank, and the exterior surface was painted. Quite a lot of painting and repair work was done in the school during the vacation.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

REPORT ON STUART LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1943

Schools:

The 1943-44 term at the Lejac Indian Residential school opened September 2nd. I regret to advise that 85 pupils failed to return. It was necessary to prosecute Adanas Alexis, one of the Leading members of the Stony Creek Band under Section 10 of the Indian Act. This Indian not only refused to send his children to school, but counselled others to do likewise.

Rounding up the absentees entailed a considerable amount of work and expense for gasoline and wear and tear on tires, which we could ill afford. At the time of writing the school quota is complete.

R. Howe,
Indian Agent.

Robert Howe, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

With reference to the matters contained in the letter from Mr. Phelan, dated October 12th., I wish to make the following observations:

1. Josephine Moise, No.0439, died in Vanderhoof hospital, after having spent several months in Smithers Hospital and at home.

2. Peter Abraham was X-rayed at Vanderhoof Hospital before he came to this school, and you informed me orally that the results were negative.

4. Margaret Andrews is being X-rayed October 23rd., in the semi-annual T.B. clinic at this school.

5. Raymond Seymour has had tonsils; but in view of the fact that he suffers no physical discomfort or toxic effects, we had intended to have him operated on at the time of our annual "tonsil clinic" later on in the year, thereby avoiding unnecessary expense.

6. Nancy Anatole is now in good physical condition; the only defect being in her vision, which can be corrected by using spectacles.

If the Department declines to approve the admission of the four children, Peter Abraham, Margaret Andrews, Raymond Seymour and Nancy Anatole, I shall have to send them home; since they all come from remote areas they will be far removed from all medical supervision and care, which they are now receiving at this school.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Robert Howe, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Mr. Howe:

Maxine George, chief of the Fort Fraser Band, has asked me to have his daughter Louise, age 16, re-admitted to this school. Louise last year made her Grade VII, and it is her father's wish that she finish Grade VIII, with the idea that she may go on to High School later.

Therefore, I enclose herewith an "Application for Admission" form, duly filled out; and I beg that you forward this request, with your own approbation, to the Department at Ottawa. Personally, I am in favour of this girl, Louise M. George, being re-admitted to the school for the above purpose. She is a good student and has always given satisfaction in every way during the 8 years she has already spent here.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

GENERAL REPORT

for quarter ending December 31st., 1943.

ATTENDANCE
All through the past quarter we have been well in excess of our pupilage quota, and at the moment there are 153 children in the school, despite the fact that six children were sent to the hospital for T.B. treatment.

MORALE
This has kept up remarkably well, and although the principal was absent for several weeks not one child attempted to run away. During the Christmas holidays we had about 175 parents and relatives of the children here for the Christmas concert, and all of them seemed to be quite satisfied with the condition of their children; which would indicate that the children themselves are contented.

HEALTH
During the survey made by the T.B. Travelling Clinic at this school about 130 children were X-rayed. Consequently, six children had to be sent for hospital treatment. Two children have returned here after lengthy sojourns at the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital.

For about six weeks, beginning the first of November, the school was quarantined for Mumps; 120 children in all being affected. One little girl, seven years old, died in Vanderhoof Hospital.

MANUAL TRAINING
This is proceeding along the customary lines. Due to the fact that there are no big boys this year, the boys are not giving as much assistance with the farm work as in other years. The work of rebuilding the chicken house which burned down in November 1942 is now completed. Operations have been suspended in the shoe repair shop due to the difficulty in obtaining materials.

LIVESTOCK
The results of the sale of cattle this year were rather disappointing due to a sudden slump in prices just before the sale. The results from the sheep were quite satisfactory. Due to the shortage of feed we disposed of 30 suckling calves, which would normally have been held over until next year.

SUPPLIES
It is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain sufficient clothing for the children, especially shirts and overalls. Leather for shoe-repair is also very scarce. The rubbers and running shoes made from reclaimed rubber are very unsatisfactory.

Rev. Alex R. Simpson, O.M.I.

LEFAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

GENERAL REPORT

for quarter ending March 31st., 1944.

ATTENDANCE
The attendance has remained at a steady level all through the past quarter. The average for the quarter is over 160. The Department has recently notified us that three indigent children are being sent here from Lower Post. This will make about thirty such children, with the additional burden of keeping them in school all during the summer vacation. It is only just that some recognition of this be made by the Department, such as raising our number of grant earning pupils to 160.

MORALE
The children continue to be in good spirits, and another quarter has passed without any cases of truancy. In fact, we have not had a single runaway during the current school year.

HEALTH
This has been somewhat better during the past quarter. Many of the children have had colds and the 'flu, but nothing very serious. One girl was sent to hospital for six weeks as a precaution against T.B. One other girl went to hospital with sores on her legs. The children were all immunized against diphtheria. Two of the children who were sent to hospital last fall, as a result of the T.B. chest clinic, have died.

MANUAL TRAINING
This is going on as usual. We have received a welcome addition to our tool supplies from the Department. Activity is being resumed in the shoe repair shop since we have been able to obtain a supply of leather.

The girls have been doing good work in making useful garments out of the supplies of discarded army and air force clothing that we have been receiving lately.

LIVESTOCK
All of the livestock have weathered the winter in a satisfactory manner. The new crop of XXXXX calves and lambs is now arriving daily. We got 500 Barred Rock Pullet chicks late in February. This is the first time we have had anything but Leghorns.

GENERAL
It is earnestly hoped that we will be able to have the exterior woodwork of the building repaired and painted this year. During the very cold weather it was impossible to heat parts of the building due to the looseness of the windows and doors.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Mr. Howe:  
Re: #0434 - Theresa Abraham.

In a letter recently received from Mr. Philip Phelan I received the following instruction:

"No. 0434 Theresa Abraham, nineteen years of age should be discharged at the end of June."

You will remember that you interviewed this girl a short time ago; and that you decided that it would be best for her to remain in school for the present, due to her physical condition, her desire to remain here, and the nature of the reserve at Bear Lake, to which she would have to go.

I am also of the opinion that this girl should remain here until her convalescence from Infantile Paralysis is more nearly complete. In her present condition she would be almost helpless on the Reserve; and, if she leaves this school, she should be admitted to a hospital rather than be sent home.

Since Theresa is also anxious to continue her studies, I am willing to have her remain in school for the next school year.

Will you please take this matter up with the Department, and see what can be done?

Yours very truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Mrs. Antonia Jack, a widow of Atlin-Teslin Lake Band and the mother of six children, has asked that her boy Sylvester, aged 11 years 5 months, now attending Lejac Indian Residential School, be returned home in order to help her and to learn to trap.

Sylvester was admitted to Lejac School in March, 1941, and is apparently making normal progress. While I am disinclined to recommend the discharge of pupils before they reach the age of sixteen years, this case is exceptional in that the widowed mother needs the help of a son and also it is important that Sylvester learns to trap during the next three or four years or it will take him much longer to learn later. From past experience it seems these Indian boys do not take well to trapping after they are sixteen or older.

Mrs. Jack has a girl, age 10 also in Lejac School and has asked that two younger children, aged 8 and 6 years, be sent to school. They would have to be escorted and as the mother is destitute this expense would be a charge on the Department, as would the expense of a matron on the journey from Atlin to Lejac. The cost of this trip would be about $200.00, mainly for fares. If the boy Sylvester returned with the escort the cost would rise to $275.00.

Another factor in the case is that there is no means of having the prospective school children medically examined before leaving Atlin as there is no doctor there. They would probably have to go to Smithers first before proceeding to Lejac. The children appear healthy but their father died of pulmonary tuberculosis last June at Coqualeetza Hospital.

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending June 30th., 1944.

ATTENDANCE
The attendance has risen a little during the past quarter, with four new children being admitted. The average for the quarter was 167.89.

MORALE
Nearly all of the children seem to be very happy. There has not been a single case of truancy during the past year, that is, no child has run away from school.

HEALTH
This has been fairly good. We had a dental clinic, and the dentist was amazed at the good condition of the teeth of the older children who had been in school for several years. The general state of the teeth of the new children was quite bad.

The T.B. Clinic took X-rays of about 24 children; but, for the first time since this survey was begun, we did not have to send a single child to the Sanatorium.

One girl, Bertha Pierre, was sent to St. Paul's Hospital in Vancouver for further treatment for goitre. Today, a telegram came announcing that she had died June 29th, without any explanation.

MANUAL TRAINING
This is following the usual lines. Both boys and girls have had considerable work in the garden and greenhouse, transplanting and thinning out, etc.

One of our girls, in the Provincial T.B. Poster contest, won a first prize; another girl and boy each got honourable mention in the same contest.

We have made quite a large number of serviceable garments for the girls from the discarded army clothing we have received.

LIVESTOCK
The lamb crop was disappointing, but the calf crop has been fairly good. When our pullet chicks were about ten weeks old, one of the boys filled the feed trough with sawdust, and we lost over 200 of the chicks.

GENERAL
Due to the lack of available labour, it will not be possible to have the exterior woodwork of the school building repaired and repainted, as we had hoped.

The lack of help is also hampering our work on the farm.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, Principal

October 18th., 1944.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of October 10th. concerning Sylvester Jack, No. 407, is to hand.

It is rather surprising to me that the matter of discharging this boy should be renewed at this time; because, only last August his mother brought his little brother and sister to school, and she was quite cheerfully resigned to the fact that Sylvester could not go home this year.

However, if it is wish of the Department that he should go home, I have no objection. But, I wish to point out that this boy comes from Atlin, which is in a most remote section of Northern B.C., and that the boy is only 12 years of age. Therefore, he will have to have an escort to take him home, the more especially since the season is now far advanced and the means of transportation are very uncertain at this time of the year.

I did not consider that your letter authorised the sending of an escort with this boy; therefore, I will take no steps toward sending him home until I receive confirmation from you.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

Upon returning to my headquarters here in Whitehorse, I found your two communications of October 10 and 24 with enclosed correspondence of Agent Benson and Father Simpson re Sylvester Jack's return to Atlin.

I wish to thank you for your earnestness in taking this matter up.

As stated in my letter of October 7, I was surprised to hear of Mrs. Jack's request being turned down by Ottawa, after it had been endorsed by the local Indian Agent, especially in view of the fact that Mrs. Jack had been sent purposely to Lejeu last Summer as an escort both to bring some of her younger children in and to take Sylvester back home with her. Frankly, I could not understand the attitude of the Ottawa Officials, and was anxious to have some explanation on the matter. I added that Mrs. Jack, though greatly disappointed, "accepted this painful situation without recrimination and consented to leave her boy in the school for another year."

Your explanation is somewhat satisfactory, though it shows once more the difficulty which the Ottawa Officials have to understand at such a distance our local problems and the lack of confidence they have in the report of their local Agents. I must now admit that you have gone beyond my expectations by instructing the Principal of Lejeu, at this late date, to have the boy sent home at the earliest possible date.

I wired immediately to Father Hemel, the missionary in charge at Atlin, in order to ascertain whether Mrs. Jack was still in Atlin and whether it this late date she still cared to have the boy come back to her for the present coming season. I received this morning the following wire from Father Hemel: "Sylvester Jack born November 1st 1932—stops Antonio and George with him come back as soon as possible because they go tramping after New Year." George is a first cousin to Sylvester and looks after his training.

In my estimation there is not the slightest difficulty for a boy of Sylvester's age to come back home alone. There is a steamer plying every ten days, all the winter long, between Prince Rupert and Skagway, and a connecting train between Skagway and Carcross, with a connecting plane between Carcross and Atlin. I would suggest to have Father Simpson or Agent Howe make the necessary arrangements for the boy's trip through the Indian Agent at Prince Rupert; the latter knows exactly from experience what papers are required by the Immigration for the boy's passage.

Reverend Sir:

On receipt of your letter of October 18, regarding Sylvester Jack, No. 407, I wrote to Right Reverend J.L. Coudert, O.M.I., and part of his reply reads as follows:

"I wired immediately to Father Hamel, the missionary in charge at Atlin, in order to ascertain whether Mrs. Jack was still in Atlin and whether at this late date she still cared to have the boy come back to her for the present trapping season. I received this morning the following wire from Father Hamel: 'Sylvester Jack born November 1st, 1932 - stop - Antonia and George wish him come back as soon as possible because they go trapping after New Year.' George is a first cousin to Sylvester and looks after his trapline.

"In my estimation there is not the slightest difficulty for a boy of Sylvester's age to come back home alone. There is a steamer plying every ten days, all the winter long, between Prince Rupert and Skagway, and a connecting train between Skagway and Carcross, with a connecting plane between Carcross and Atlin. I would suggest to have father Simpson or Agent Howe make the necessary arrangements for the boy's trip through the Indian Agent at Prince Rupert; the latter knows exactly from experience what papers are required by the Immigration for the boy's passage from Prince Rupert to Atlin, via Skagway and Carcross; he, then, would have only to put the boy on the steamer at Prince Rupert, and wire George Simmons of the Northern Airways at Carcross to get the boy on his arrival at Carcross by train, pending favorable weather conditions for the plane to take off for Atlin."

Rev. A.R. Simpson, O.M.I.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Lejac, B.C.
In view of the above information, you should arrange to have Sylvester Jack returned home at the earliest possible date.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Mr. J. Gillett, Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, British Columbia, in order that he may have complete information regarding the boy's movement and will be in a position to advise you when to send him to Prince Rupert.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, March 8, 1945.

Mr. S. Mallinson, Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C.

I desire to refer to your letter of the 3rd instant, regarding Irene Isadore, and to confirm our night lettergram of the 7th instant, stating that it was considered undesirable to place this girl in the Lejac Residential School.

The majority of the children in our residential schools today are under 16 years of age, although, in special cases, if requested by the Principal and recommended by the agent, we are prepared to approve children remaining until 18. Owing to unsatisfactory home conditions, such action is often advisable, especially in the case of the girls.

We considered the information contained in your letter, regarding the past conduct of Irene Isadore. While there is no doubt that she should be detained in some institution for a time, we do not want our Indian residential schools turned into penal institutions. It is felt that the placing of a girl with her background in a residential school would be a retrograde step and almost inevitably the other children would suffer.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I strongly recommend that this girl be allowed to enter the Lejac Indian Residential School for whatever period the Juvenile Judge deems fit. The application form will be submitted directly this girl has passed her medical examination.

GENERAL REPORT

For quarter ending March 31st., 1945.

ATTENDANCE

This went up to a high of 178 during the quarter, and has varied very little during that time. According to the quarterly returns, our average has been a little over 174 for the past quarter, almost 10% over our per capita allotment.

MORALE

On the whole, the children all appear to be contented and settled down. There have not been any runaways during the quarter, and the behaviour of the children has been consistently good.

HEALTH

As regards the health of the student body, this has been one of the best periods in my experience. Very few children have had to be put to bed, and most of these were merely cases of severe colds or of influenza. Only four children had to be taken to the hospital. One of these, Matilda David, No. 0436, developed a heart condition which seemed to be due to a previous attack of St. Vitus Dance two years ago. Her condition deteriorated very rapidly, and she died two days after being taken to the hospital.

We had a six day dental clinic for the children. The dentist was very well impressed with the condition of the children's teeth, as compared with those of white children in the locality, or elsewhere. Exactly 50% of the student body did not require any attention. The great majority of the work done was for children who were spending their first year in school. Evidently, having a clinic for the children once a year pays dividends.

LIVESTOCK

The stock are not doing so well this winter, the milk production is below previous levels, and so is the egg production. One of the main causes is the shortage of feed and grain. Last year we had an 80% crop failure due to the severe drought. Already, I have spent over $3000.00 this winter in the purchase of hay and grain.

Another contributing factor is the shortage of farm labour. Our present farm manager is not up to the standard of previous ones, and we are also short-handed. Due to the fact that there are no really big boys, we do not get very much help from them.

There was a very heavy snow fall this winter, and the continued cold weather seems to indicate that we will be quite late in getting to work on the land this year; which is another cause of anxiety.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

Re: Theresa Abraham, No.0424

Mr. Indian Agent Howe has conveyed to me your remarks re the above pupil, following your examination of the March quarter returns for this school.

Since there has been considerable correspondence concerning this girl each year about this time, I must presume that you are familiar with the facts of this case; and in view of these facts I find it hard to understand your arbitrary demand for her discharge.

Last year, and the year before, I had to beg the Department to allow this girl to remain in school, but I do not intend to do so again. It is not reasonable that I should have to beg for the privilege of saving money for the Department. If this girl has to leave the school, the only place where she can receive adequate care, and entertain any hope of further improvement in her condition, is in the hospital. Here she is under constant medical supervision, she receives daily massage and other attention. If she returns to her home at Bear Lake, a most isolated and primitive reserve, she will certainly not enjoy these advantages.

You say, "it will not be possible to pay grant for her after that date (June 30, 1945)." May I point out that our average attendance for the past fiscal year was 171.87; and that we were allowed grant for only 160 children? It is obvious, therefore, that we enjoy no financial advantage by keeping this girl in school; our only motive in doing so is a wish to give her a chance for recovery from her ailment.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Mr. Howe:

For the past several years there has been an increase every year in the number of children remaining here at the school for the two months of the summer vacation. This summer there will be about 44 children here all during vacation.

This condition is due to the fact that we have been accepting indigent and neglected children from the Stikine Agency, as well as orphans and neglected children from your own agency; and in the summer time these children have no place to go, or their homes are too far away or too remote to allow them to go home. We have also two incorrigibles from the Vancouver Agency.

As you can understand, this means a great deal of extra expense for us, for the feeding and clothing of these children, and for the necessary staff to look after them. No provision for this is made by the Department, because the grant now received covers only the ten months of the school year, as was stated in the House of Commons last August by the Hon. Mr. Crear.

During the past winter we had a great deal of extra expense due to the crop failure of last year; and the prospects for a good crop this year are not very bright. Consequently, our resources are severely strained by the ordinary expenditures of the school year, without having the extra expense of taking care of such a large number of children for two whole months without any compensation. As far as I am aware, no other school has such a problem. Next year it will be still worse, for Mr. Sampson, Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek has notified me that he intends to send down seven more indigent children this fall; and I am extremely reluctant to refuse to accept these children.

Therefore, I beg that you bring this matter to the attention of the proper authorities in the Indian Department with a view to obtaining a supplementary grant, possibly from the Welfare Branch, to assist us in taking care of these indigent children during the summer months.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

The parents of the below-described children have asked for their admission to residential school:

To Carcross School, Doreen Dennis, age 15, of Tahltan Band. This girl will be 16 in September, 1945, and although the mother is anxious for the girl to attend school for at least two terms, I do not recommend the admission unless the Department feels a special concession may be granted in this case to allow her to attend school until she is 18. The mother will provide transportation to school. Faith, C.of E.

To Lejac School, Mabel Frank, age 14, of Tahltan Band. This girl's father is dead, and the mother is drawing relief. The girl has suffered from a discharging sore at the back of her right ear, which, according to a U.S. Army medical officer, is caused by a diseased condition of the bone, since last winter. From appearance the girl is obviously in need of expert medical attention. It is suggested that she proceed to Smithers Hospital for medical attention, and when her condition is improved, be sent to Lejac School. Faith, R.C.

To Lejac School, Viola Jack, age 13, of Atlin-Teslin Lake Band. This girl's father is apparently a pulmonary T.B. case and may be going to hospital shortly. The girl last winter suffered from a cataract-like condition of both eyes, and for a period had great difficulty in seeing. The trouble has cleared up to some extent but it is apparent that she needs medical attention to ensure that her eye-sight is protected. It is suggested that she also go to Smithers for medical attention, and ultimate admission to Lejac, as her faith is Roman Catholic.

It is planned to send these girls out under the care of Mrs. Henry, referred to in a previous letter as requiring medical attention in Prince Rupert. The cost of
the fares for Mabel Frank and Viola Jack will be about $50.00 each, plus about $10.00 to $15.00 possible expenses enroute, but there would be no matron's fee. Will the Department please authorize this expense if they approve of this suggestion. An airmail reply would be appreciated.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 19, 1945.

Mr. R.H.S. Sampson, Indian Agent,

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, the Department approves the admission of Mabel Frank and Viola Jack to the Lejac Residential School, provided that they are physically fit to enter a residential school when they have received the medical treatment which you state they require. I have noted the expenses that will be necessary to cover their transportation.

In view of the information contained in the first paragraph of your letter, the Department does not consider it advisable to send Doreen Dennis to the Carcross School.

Philip Phelan,

I enclose herewith an application for the admission of Martha Joseph, age 12, to the Lejac Indian Residential School.

For a number of years Martha has been taken care of by her grandmother, who recently died, and I am certain it would be to the child's advantage to enter the above mentioned school, which I recommend. Martha Joseph was never supported by her father, who had left her mother several years ago.

With reference to the child's health, she has a touch of scabies on one leg, which is under treatment and a cure will be effected before she enters Lejac.

I am informed by the Principal that she will be accepted if approved by the Department.

S. Mallinson,
