Dear Mr. Irvine:

During your recent visit to the school, which we enjoyed very much, you will remember that I told you that I had a request to make of you, and you told me to put it in writing and send it to Ottawa. Well, here it is.

Each Indian Residential school has a certain quota of pupils allotted to it by the Department of Indian Affairs. Our official number of pupils is 160. Each quarter we have to send in an attendance report, and, if the average daily attendance for the quarter is under 160 even by half a pupil, a corresponding amount is deducted from the per capita grant for the quarter in question. But, no matter how many children we have over our allotted number, nothing is paid for the extra pupils.

My request is that the per capita grant to the Residential Schools be based on the actual number of pupils present in the school. At the moment we have 192 children, but our grant is only for 160; so we have to carry the additional 32 children without any assistance from the Indian Department.

The objection may be raised that such an arrangement will cause the principals to overcrowd their schools in order to get the extra grant. Every single admission to a Residential School has to be authorised by Ottawa before the child can be placed on the rolls as a grant-earning pupil, so this gives the Department a means of controlling the pupilage in all the schools. Besides, it is a well known fact that a large proportion of the Indian children in Canada are without any facilities for education; therefore the schools should be encouraged to accept as many pupils as they can without detriment to the efficient operation of the school. Even crowded quarters in a Residential School are, in most cases, incomparably superior to the home accommodations.

Trusting that I have made myself clear, and thanking you in advance for your valued interest, I remain,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Nurse Dunn has reported the following case and asks for immediate action to prevent further contacts:

Isobel Reid, age 30, unmarried Indian woman of Tahltan Band, and the mother of two children namely, Bertha, age 5, and a baby, age 16 months. Suspected of having pulmonary tuberculosis so sputum samples sent out for bacteriological examination. Report received from Provincial Laboratories February 16 states last two tests show positive sputum for pulmonary tuberculosis. This woman is coughing extensively, has weakness and night temperature, and has not menstruated since the birth of her last child, October 10, 1944.

Miss Dunn has strongly recommended the isolation of the mother from the two children and steps have been taken to have the children cared for temporarily, but it is probable that 100 percent isolation will not be achieved owing to the fact that the mother's tent is close to the tent where the children will be staying, and there will doubtless be some visiting as neither the nurse nor myself can exercise any control or supervision. The camp in which Isobel Reid lives is some four miles from town and is difficult to reach, being across the Stikine River. There is no suitable house, or home, where the woman could be kept in Telegraph Creek. Neither is there anyone at the Camp who could be hired to take charge of Isobel Reid and look after her. This means that she must keep her own fire going, and do her cooking, so it is not possible to have her take the proper treatment of complete rest.

As the woman is an open case she is a menace to any camp or community in which she lives, as well as to her two small children. Her removal to Whitehorse Hospital at the earliest possible date is recommended.
The problem of finding a suitable home for the children also arises. The woman has only one sister, Mrs. Maggie Jackson, who already has eight children of her own and could not be burdened with two extra. It is therefore suggested that Bertha, age 5, be admitted to Lejac Residential School when navigation opens on the Stikine River. Mrs. Jackson can probably be persuaded to look after Bertha until that time. It may be possible to send one or two other children to Lejac at the same time.

At the present time the only suggestion I have concerning the baby, age 16 months, is the Catholic Home in Edmonton and it may be possible to arrange removal of this child with the Ward children whose removal was authorized by the Department's telegram of February 11.

The three separate recommendations contained in this letter are:

(1) To hospitalize Isobel Reid in Whitehorse immediately pending removal to Miller Bay Hospital this coming summer. Cost of removal to Whitehorse will be about $100.00 including meals & hotel room enroute.

(2) To admit Bertha Reid, age 5, to Lejac Indian Residential School next May. Cost, if combined with removal of other school children, about $125.00

(3) To remove the baby to Catholic Institution in Edmonton, probably to travel as far as Whitehorse with mother, then join Ward children for trip to Edmonton. Cost approximately $50.00

If the Department approves these recommendations it would be appreciated if they could advise by night letter so that Isobel Reid can be removed from the proximity of her children as soon as possible. I am also anxious to know about the removal of the baby before final arrangements are made about removal of the Ward children previously referred to.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.

GENERAL REPORT
For quarter ending March 31st., 1946.

ATTENDANCE

Due to the number of children that had to go to the hospital the attendance average for the past quarter is slightly lower. This would have been much lower had it not been for the cooperation of Mr. Indian agent Howe in refusing many requests on the part of the parents to take their children out of school for one reason or another.

MORALE

The children maintain a good spirit, and there has not been a single case of truancy since the beginning of the current school year. Some of the parents send letters to the children containing abuse of the school and its authorities; but the children do not seem to pay very much attention to such epistles.

HEALTH

This has been the worst period with regard to the health of children in all my experience here. Early in February we had a flu epidemic with about 65 children being in bed at the same time. This was almost cleared up when another outbreak occurred at the beginning of March, during which we had 145 children in bed simultaneously with four Sisters and several other members of the staff. This was rather a terrible period. Now we have about 15 children still in bed running some fever. The children have been slow in shaking off the after effects of this flu, and are not entirely recovered even yet. I had the school doctor apply to the Department for a supply of vitamins for the children, but as yet we have had no response. Another request for a supply of tin tablets to counteract none in several of the children has also been ignored.

Due to a series of accidents we have been unable to have an X-ray survey here this year, and this is particularly unfortunate because I feel sure that there are some very active T.B. cases among the children that should be detected and isolated.

LIVESTOCK

The constant need for the purchasing of feed at high prices for the cattle is a serious drain on our resources. The winter has been a very long one and we still have over two feet of snow on the fields which means that it will be a long time before the cattle can be turned out to pasture.

GENERAL REMARKS

The following items have been brought to the attention of the Department before in these quarterly reports without producing any reaction whatsoever; but I will repeat them again now.

1. The hot water supply is absolutely inadequate for the needs of the children.

2. Additional space is required at this school in the form of more dormitory and dining-room facilities; and a hall for indoor recreation. All this could be taken care of by the addition of a single wing to the present building.

3. Due to the increasing difficulty in obtaining cordwood, and the oft repeated objections of the parents to their children having to work with firewood, it is suggested that the Department consider the possibility of converting the present heating system to an oil-burning installation.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

Last week Mrs. Etzerza came here from Telegraph Creek as escort to two small children coming to this school. She herself has four children here now. There is another daughter, Irma, at home who is now 16 years old and who had had a certain amount of instruction in Day School.

According to what Mrs. Etzerza told me, she applied to the local Indian Agent two years ago to have Irma sent to this school in order to get further education in the grades and some vocational training. The Indian Agent refused to make application on the grounds that the girl was already 14 years old, so it was not worth sending her down here for only two years. Irma still wants to come here, and I promised her mother that I would take the case up with you. I am sure that Ottawa would approve her admission for vocational training in Home Economics, Dressmaking and Hygiene, if it were proposed by you.

At the present time I am negotiating with a Registered Nurse in the hope that she will accept the position of School Nurse here. The Hon. Brooks Claxton informed the Joint Committee on the Indian Act that it was the intention of his department to employ qualified nurses to be stationed in the larger residential schools. I trust that this provision can be applied to this school. Your opinion on this matter will be much appreciated.

Dear Bishop Coudert:

Acknowledging your telegram of the 2nd instant with reference to the admission of Irma Etzerza to Lejac Indian Residential School, I would advise that the matter has been referred to the Department.

It is regretted that the Reverend Principal feels that what he considers the difficulties in this case are due to personal animus on the part of the Indian Agent as I am strongly of the opinion that this is not the case.

It was known here that five years ago this family were regarded as Anglicans and the girl, Irma, attended the Tahltan Indian Seasonal school which was under Anglican auspices. Unfortunately the Indian Agent, when writing about this case did not advise of the family's baptism into the Catholic faith and we followed the same procedure as we have previously where the situation was reversed and it was proposed to admit Catholic children to a Protestant Institution.

There was also the question of permitting an Indian girl of this age to travel alone for a journey of this nature.

Agent Sampson thought that as the girl's mother applied to have her sent to Grouard Residential School this would meet her situation and he referred it to you but I have not been advised of the outcome.

I enclose herewith a file of correspondence regarding the admission of a girl of the Tahltan Band in the Sukine Indian Agency to Lejac Indian Residential School.

At the time the writer inspected this Agency in 1941 this girl was attending the Tahltan seasonal day school operated under the auspices of the local Anglican missionary and the family were considered of that faith. She is now sixteen years of age.

An application for her admission was received from the Reverend Principal of Lejac in August and was referred to the Indian Agent, Mr. Sampson, who advised, and I believe with a great deal of reason, that she was really too old to benefit a great deal from the two year period of training proposed, and that the cost of sending her with necessary escort would have amounted to $150; also, that the girl's mother has applied for her admission to Croscad Residential School Co-operative, the location of which is unknown at this office. It will be noted that Agent Sampson forwarded it to Bishop Coudert, but I have not heard of the result. In the meantime the Reverend Principal has been very insistent in the matter and apparently has accepted the impression created by his missionary, Father Forget, at Telegraph Creek, that the Indian Agent is obstructing them unreasonably, and both he and Bishop Coudert have adopted a somewhat threatening attitude in the matter.

Agent Sampson knows the girl, and would have been unwise in agreeing, in any event, to her proceeding on this lengthy journey alone. It is a days journey down the Sukine to Wrangell, Alaska, where she would certainly need more protection, in this town, than would likely be afforded by the cook on the boat. There is no assurance that the arrival of the river boat will coincide with the steamer to Prince Rupert, and several days may elapse. She would be alone on the Prince Rupert boat which...
would be undesirable. On arrival there she would separately be met and cared for by Father Carroll until the train left at 1:30 p.m., but would be unescorted until it arrived at Lejac late the following afternoon. Under these circumstances I hesitate to recommend approval of her admission without an escort and it is unlikely that the escort could be able to return owing to navigation closing on the Stikine. It might be possible for the Agent to arrange for her care by some reliable person going out for the winter.

If you wish to approve of her admission it would be appreciated if you would telegraph Mr. Sampson direct.

For D. H. MacKay,

I beg to submit hereunder, my general report for
the quarter ending September 30th, 1946:

SCHOOLS

The Lejac Indian Residential School term opened
September 3rd last. Over 100 absentees were reported
at the opening date. Despite the efforts of the Agency
Staff and local R.C.M.P., there are still 35 truants,
chiefly from the Stony Creek Band. This matter was
covered by my report dated Sept. 12th, file no. E-2.
With reference to the Department's reply, action will
shortly be taken under the Indian Act, against some
of the parents of the Stony Creek Band who have not
returned their children to School.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

An application has been received from the guardians of Susie Johnson, born 16th November 1931, of Atlin Band, for her admission to Lejac Residential School.

Susie is the daughter of Albert Johnson, late of Atlin Band, who was removed from membership in the Band by authority of Departmental letter 62-158 of May 23, 1944, for residence in Alaska for a period exceeding five years without formal permission.

This girl has for several years lived with Mr. and Mrs. John Anderson of Atlin Band who now wish her to be admitted to school.

The cost of sending Susie to Lejac School from Atlin would be about $250.00 including return fare for escorting matron, plus matron's wages for two weeks (if any). The guardians, who are not very well off, apparently expect the expense will be borne by the department. There would also be an expense of $65.00 for returning this girl in about a year's time.

In view of the age of this girl,(15) it is not felt that removal for a year or two schooling warrants the high cost involved. Besides this the girl's father has not supported her for at least five years, and has abandoned her to the care of relatives entirely. Johnson maintains a home in Juneau, Alaska, and could very well keep the girl there and send her to school. He earns good wages most of the year from fishing and mining.

It would be appreciated if the Department will cont'd.
advise this office of their views in this case as soon as possible.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.

1. With reference to the above, at the a.m., of the 12th instant, the following letter was received at this office:

BEGINS:
Dear Sir Re Martha Irene JOSEPH December 11th, 1946.
It appears that the above child, born August 17th, 1935, daughter of Dan Joseph of Tsitlak Reserve, a Roman Catholic, was taken care of by Mrs Kate of Kispiox and later by Mrs Alfred William (Matilda) Brown of Hazelton. She was enrolled as a pupil of Lejac Indian Residential School but failed to return and is reportedly attending Hazelton Indian Day School.

The Rev Principal of Lejac Residential School requires her return and under Section 10(2) of the Indian Act he is on solid ground in protesting her attendance at school under Protestant auspices, and I have no option but to require her return to his school in the absence of any valid reason why she should not do so.

It would be appreciated if you would kindly take whatever action is necessary to ensure her return to Lejac School.

Yours truly,

(Signed) James Coleman
R.C.M.P.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sub-Division

2. In the p.m., of the 12th instant, Mr & Mrs Alfred W. BROWN, the foster parents of this child, were interviewed at their home on the Hazelton Indian Reserve and were informed of the contents of the above letter and were instructed to have the child returned to the Lejac Residential School. They at first were reluctant to comply with the instructions but after some discussion, they stated that she would be returned to the school in question. However, they requested that she be permitted to remain at home for the Christmas Holidays in order to give them time to get her clothing in proper condition and also give the girl the opportunity of spending the Christmas Season amongst her relatives and friends.

This request was reported to Inspector Coleman on the 12th instant, and he advised that under the circumstances he thought it would be in order for the girl to stay at home for the period requested but that she must report to the Lejac School not later than January 4th, 1947. The foster parents were informed accordingly.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

I am in receipt of copies of correspondence under your file 215.12.5341 in connexion with sending Irma Etzerza to Lejac School.

It is rather surprising to learn that so much concern was shown by the members of the R.C. Church in this area over getting this girl out to school, and I find it very difficult to understand why not one of these gentlemen approached the R.C.T.S. with a request or recommendation for her removal. In view of her age (16) it is all the more surprising as only this year the Reverend Principal of Lejac discharged two of our children at 16, one of them a girl Evelyn Reid, whose both parents are dead, and the other a motherless boy with a very poor home. (Robert Quock). If I had known of his desire to keep the children until 18 years of age I certainly would have urged he keep both these children. Irma Etzerza has a good home compared with what Evelyn Reid had to look forward to.

Mrs Mary Etzerza asked this office once, in the summer of 1945, if Irma might be sent to Lejac school. She was advised that owing to Irma's age (then nearly 15) I was not anxious to send her for only a year or two's schooling. Irma had at that time only been baptised into the Roman Catholic Church for a matter of a very few weeks. Early this spring Mrs Etzerza asked about sending her daughters Peggy (18) and Irma to the Grouard Residential School in Alberta where girls are kept after they are 16 to learn special trades. Enquiries were made about this proposal and from the report received from the Reverend Principal of that institution I feel that Irma would have had a much better chance of learning something constructive. The girl Peggy could also have gone there.

I think it would perhaps be advisable to clear up any doubt about this office obstructing the members of the R.C. Church, and exhibiting personal animosity in dealing with this case. This is absolutely false and the Reverend Principal of Lejac certainly has no grounds upon which to make such an assertion. This is especially true when one considers that he did not even communicate with this office concerning the case. Neither did Rev. Forget discuss the case at all. My treatment of this particular case was quite impartial, and if anything, this family has received considerable sympathetic attention owing to Mrs. Etzerza being a widow with a large family.

It might also be of interest to mention that Mrs. Etzerza states that the Rev. Principal of Lejac told her Irma would be allowed to stay at Lejac until perhaps she was 25 years old, and this, she claims induced her to request Father Simpson to admit her.

1. With reference to the above, on the 28th instant, the following letter was received at this office:

Dear Sir,

The above named child, aged fifteen next March 20th, whose mother, Christine Alex, died on February 1st, 1946, was removed from the Reserve by Rev. Father Godfrey of Smithers to Lejac Residential School probably last month "because she was getting in trouble there" (Reserve or Smithers) at that time being in the care of her sister, Mrs Clara George, who was drawing her family allowance although it is stated that she did very little for the girl. Father Donz says that she attended school at Hagwilget very irregularly. Both parents being dead the signing of the admission will devolve upon the Indian Agent.

Long standing department instructions are to the effect that no child is to be removed from a Reserve on which a day school is operating to a residential school without first taking the matter up with them, explaining why such action would be desirable for the child. Not having personal knowledge of this girl's circumstances I am not in position to make a report, particularly as I am lacking transportation.

It would be appreciated if you could make inquiries on the reserve with a view to supporting the desirability of this girl being transferred from the care of her sister to the school in question and let me have same in duplicate.

Yours truly,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

2. A number of complaints have been received in the past regarding the conduct of this girl particularly in connection with her irregular attendance at the Taltak Indian day school. The mother, when alive, and the sister since the death of the mother, have been warned regarding the girl's non-attendance at the school. Both of these relations claimed the girl was difficult to handle and would not heed them when instructed to go to school. Since the closing of the Taltak School in June, 1946, this girl, of course, has received no educational instructions.

3. On November 18th, 1946, Father Bonze, O.M.I., of the Taltak Indian Reserve, called at this office and advised that this girl had left her sister's home on the reserve and had gone to Smithers, B.C., and would not return. He stated that she was employed in a Chinese restaurant, and, as this did not appear to be a proper environment for a girl of this age, he and the sister asked that she be return to the Reserve or moved to better employment.
Immediate enquiries were made regarding this complaint and it was ascertained that the B.C.P. Police, Smithers, B.C., were endeavoring to locate the girl and no assistance was required by this detachment. However, whilst on patrol in Smithers, B.C., on the 21-11-46, the N.C.O./Cpl. B.C.P. Police was interviewed and he stated that the girl had not been found but she was not working in any of the restaurants at that point. He advised that a sharp lookout was being maintained and when the girl was found, appropriate action would be taken. Shortly following this interview, the B.C.P. Police informed me that the girl had been taken by Father Godfrey and sent to the Lejac Residential School.

The home life and general environment of this girl have been very poor and very little control of her activities could be maintained by her relations. Past complaints of her conduct have been minor but she is now reaching the age where she could get into a great deal of trouble unless positive measures are taken to correct the situation. There is no doubt that the enrolment of this juvenile in an appropriate institution will be of great benefit to her.

Duplicate copies of this report handed to the Inspector of Indian Agencies at Hazelton, B.C.

Inspector J. Coleman,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Hazelton, B.C.

January 5th, 1947

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

On the 11th ult. I received enclosed Admission Form for Violet Mary Wilson, aged fifteen, apparently the illegitimate daughter of Christine Alex of Tsitsik Reserve who died last February.

As there is a day school on the Reserve, temporarily closed but expected to open shortly, and I had no knowledge of the girl nor transportation to make enquiries, I referred the matter to the local R.C.M.P. officer, asking him to make enquiries and his report is so complete that there is little that I can add to it. It clearly indicates that the girl will be better in the school for another year although I am of the opinion that the missionaries should consult this office before removing a girl to a residential school without permission as in this case. Such a procedure is likely to give rise to complications.

Having no relatives I have signed the admission in the usual way and would recommend approval of same.

(James Coleman)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

I am in receipt of a letter from Rev Father Simpson O.M.I., Principal of Lejac Indian School, enclosing a letter from Mrs. Thomas George, an enfranchised Indian woman of Telwa, B.C.. Mrs. George states that she has been acting as foster mother to Margaret Joseph, born September 1, 1942.

Margaret Joseph is the daughter of the late Mary Pierre who died in 1943, since when, the child has been cared for by a succession of relatives. Sam Pierre married Mary Tom in 1936, shortly afterwards they separated and Sam Pierre went to live with another Indian woman while Mary, nee Tom, had one or two more children by another man thought to be Frank Joseph. Since the mother's death the child has been unwanted wherever she went. The present foster mother, Mrs. Thomas George, requests a place for the child in Lejac School. Father Simpson states his willingness to accept her in view of the circumstances and despite her tender years, and I recommend her placement at the school. Her religion is definitely Roman Catholic.

I should appreciate your decision in the matter.

Ottawa, March 24th, 1947.

Mr. R.H.S. Sampson, Indian Agent,
Telegraph Creek, B.C.

We have your letter of the 27th ultimo with reference to the discharge of Ira Etzerza from the Lejac School.

We are writing the Principal of the Lejac School to ascertain what progress the boy is making. Our information is that he is only fourteen years of age and if he is making good progress at school it seems unreasonable to make him sacrifice his opportunity for the rest of the family.

I would be interested in knowing the age of the other children who are residing with the mother. What does the mother do to provide a living for the other members of the family?

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Ira Etzerza, age 14, of Tahltan Band, was admitted to Lejac Residential School in July, 1944, and now his mother is asking that he be discharged and returned home to assist her.

At the time this boy was sent to school his mother was a widow, destitute, and with eleven children, eight of whom were under sixteen years of age. The oldest son, age 19, was helping his mother at that time, but has since moved away from the family, leaving the mother with no one to help her in providing wood, in gardening, or in hunting.

The mother, Mrs. James Low, was married last fall to a white who subsequently failed to provide support for the family, resulting in his wife leaving him and returning to her former home at Telegraph Creek. She is without support and certainly needs the assistance of this boy Ira.

Replying to the Department's enquiry of April 15, which was only received here June 7 owing to a delay in the mail, I beg to advise that as stated in my letter of February 27, the oldest son Ralph, age 19, does not stay at home, and is of no assistance to his mother. Since this boy became 16 years of age he has not lived with his family for more than a few weeks, and although he has earned good revenue from his trap-line he has not assisted either his widowed mother, or his infant brothers.

The advisability of bringing the boy Ira back from school was thoroughly considered before application was made on February 27, and it was felt that in view of all attending circumstances his return home was best. The fact that he can probably be promoted to Grade VI next year is of no particular advantage to him when he returns to his home. His livelihood will be made from trapping, hunting, and labouring. As a matter of fact he will likely learn more of value to him in future life if he returns home and goes out trapping next winter. It has been found in the past that if these young boys do not learn the art of trepping in their early teens they have some difficulty mastering it later. Apart from these facts there is also the urgent need of the widowed mother for the assistance of the boy. She lives at the old Tahltan village, a mile from the nearest camp and thirteen miles from town, and has only her oldest daughter, 22, who is not well, and four small boys, the oldest of whom is 6 yrs. She has absolutely no revenue and depends upon her garden and relief rations to feed the children. All the wood-cutting and other heavy work has to be done by herself.

I trust . . . .
I trust the Department will see fit to authorize Ira's discharge from Lejac School in the light of the foregoing facts.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.

LEJAC INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

GENERAL REPORT
For quarter ending June 30th., 1947.

ATTENDANCE

The level of attendance was very constant all through the quarter. Five new pupils were admitted and two others returned from the hospital early in April.

MORALE

The children have shown good spirit all through the past school year. If only the parents were as satisfied as their children our task here would be much easier. During the whole of the year just ended we did not have a single case of truancy.

HEALTH

There was very little sickness during this period. Only two children had to be hospitalised, and that for comparatively minor ailments. Since last February we have had a qualified nurse (she is not a Sister) on the staff; which has been a considerable drain on our resources since she has to have quite a high salary; but she has done well and seems quite capable.

At the end of May we had an X-ray clinic at which about 60 of the children had plates made.

GENERAL REMARKS

1. This summer we are having the whole exterior woodwork and the roof of the main building repaired and painted - thanks to the generosity of the Department. The roof will also be rebuilt - the Dept. paying for the materials and the School paying for the labour.

2. We expect to complete the four-roomed house for the farm manager and his family which was started last year, and for which it has been extremely difficult to obtain materials. All of the work was done by the Manual Training Instructor and the boys.

3. All of the cement floors in the basement are to be painted this summer - at our own expense.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

Ottawa, August 7, 1947.

Rev. A.R. Simpson, O.M.I., Principal, Lejac Indian Residential School, Lejac, British Columbia.

With reference to the June Quarter Return of the Lejac Indian Residential School, it is noted that pupil No. 0505 and pupil No. 0506 were absent during the December Quarter but were shown on the March and June Quarters. I have had several cases recently wherein Native boys of school age living in Smithers where there is no Indian Day School have been convicted of theft in Juvenile Court, because there is no responsible person in their homes and because of unsatisfactory home environment. The judge requested my assistance in disposing of the cases.

There exists in B.C. of course a Boys Industrial School to which youngsters can be committed but it has been my experience that unless a child is a habitual offender and incorrigible that he will frequently be discharged from such an institution very much worse for the experience.

In these recent cases therefore, since the offences were of a minor nature and since the offenders had not appeared in Court before, I felt that by far the best answer to the problem was to send them to the Indian Residential School at Lejac, more particularly because I know that this institution has not its full quota of pupils for the school year.

This plan apparently does not meet with the approval of the Principal who feels that such children might not be a good influence on the others in the school. Your comments would be appreciated.

JVB/MHC

I desire to refer to your letter of the 17th of November and our reply of December 5th with reference to placing certain Indian boys in the Lejac School. Father Mulvihill advises us that he has asked you to send the boys to whom you refer in your previous communication.

However, the point has been raised that sending this type of boy to an Indian residential school might seriously affect the discipline of the school. We are inclined to feel that in handling cases of this kind only those boys should be sent to a residential school who have committed offences of a minor nature and have not previously appeared in court.

We do not want the feeling to grow among the Indians that our residential schools are in the same class with the Provincial Industrial School to which offenders against the law are committed. We will, therefore, depend on you to exercise great discretion regarding the type of boy in the class under discussion, that should be sent to an Indian residential school rather than allow the law to take its usual course in committing them to provincial institutions.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Mrs. Antonia Jack of Atlin Band has applied for the discharge of her daughter, Susie, who will be 14 on the 19th July, from Lejac Indian Residential School. Susie was admitted in 1941 and has been at school continually since. She has attained Grade 6.

Mrs. Jack's reason for requesting the girl's discharge is that she requires her to help at home. Mrs. Jack is currently pregnant and feels that she should have her daughter's help in looking after the younger children.

While in Atlin recently, this case was discussed at some length with the Mother and Step-father of this girl, when every effort was made to make them see the wisdom of leaving the girl in school until she had graduated, to give her an opportunity to carry on to higher education or a vocation if she so desires, and for that reason her discharge is not recommended.

The Principal of Lejac School reports that this student is well mannered and applies herself to her studies and other work. In view of this it seems that this student will have a good chance of benefiting by further education.

The parents expect the cost of returning this girl will be borne by the Department. It is estimated this expense will amount to just under $100., providing she returns home without an escort, but owing to her age it might be wiser to have her escorted by a responsible adult as the journey consumes several days by boat and train. If the Department feels this pupil's discharge is warranted will they please advise by Air Mail, at the same time authorizing the expense.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

It seems advisable to place the under-noted orphans in some institutional school as they are not receiving suitable care:

Veronica Dennis, born February 23/42 - Tahltan Band
Adolph Dennis, born July 28/39

The father of these children died in 1943, and the mother died last November. They have since been under the care of a sister, Emma Dennis, age 21, but a certain amount of neglect is evident, particularly in feeding them. Emma Dennis is an unmarried mother, and the general living conditions of the group are not satisfactory. There are no other close relations in a position to undertake the guardianship of these two children, so it is felt they will be growing up under more beneficial surroundings if they are sent to a residential school.

Three older children of this family were admitted to Lejac Indian Residential School in 1944, and this seems the best institution to which to send Veronica and Adolph who are also of Roman Catholic faith.

Removing these children will involve hiring a matron, and the complete cost including fares, expenses enroute, and return of matron is expected to total $170.00. As far as can be determined there will not be any other admissions to Lejac School this season, but if there are the children will also be sent down with the same group. It is planned to send as matron an Indian woman who has four children in Lejac School now; this will give her a visit with her children, and also enable her to have medical attention while in Prince Rupert.

If the Department approves this action...

Mrs. George Jack, 1301004 of Atlin Band, has made application for the admission of Richard, age 7, and Josephine, age 9, 1301010, children of the late Willie Jack, to a residential school this summer.

In the past such cases have been sent to the Lejac School, but with the proposed Teslin School possibly opening within the next year or two the Department may wish to delay admission of these children in view of the distance of Lejac School from the children's home in Atlin. The distance is about 900 miles, and takes from four to five days' travel by aircraft, boat, and train. The cost of sending the children to Lejac will run into nearly $300.00 by the time the return fare of a matron is paid.

There is a provincial public school in Atlin which I am sure would admit these children until they can be sent to Teslin. They have accepted native children in the past.

If the children are sent to Lejac at this time it is likely they would have to be transferred to Teslin later, at considerable expense.

No action is being taken until the Department's instructions are received.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I enclose herewith applications for admission to Lejac Residential School of Lawrence and Henry Rosso, age five and ten respectively.

These boys are the illegitimate sons of Margaret Joseph, No.58 of the Fort Babine Band, and one Tony Rosso, white, of Noralee, B.C. The parents lived together commonlaw for many years, but when Rosso's health began to fail rather more than a year ago Margaret Joseph left him. He kept the two boys and has looked after them very well. Recently, however, he wrote me that his health is now such that he is no longer employable and cannot care for the boys. I had the case investigated by the Provincial Welfare Branch who reported that the man's statements were in all respects true.

I would suggest that the best solution from the boys' point of view would be to place them in Lejac Residential School and I have written to Fr. Mulvihill, Principal, in this matter. I feel sure that he will accept Henry and I hope that he may also take Lawrence despite his tender age.

I recommend acceptance of these two boys and trust that the applications may have your endorsement.

W.V. BOYD
Indian Superintendent

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Mrs. Elizabeth Williams, of the Atlin Band, has made application for the admission of her children Anna age 14, Michael Lawrence age 8, and Andrew age 6, to Lejac Indian Residential School.

The circumstances in this case are as follows. During the latter part of December the father, Stephen Williams, was found to have tuberculosis. Williams was in turn removed to Miller Bay Hospital for treatment. Prior to his removal, the three school age children were attending the local Public School. However, when the local School Board learned of the father's condition they decided it advisable to discharge the children in the event they may have contacted the disease.

Apart from the three applicants for admission, there are four other children in this family. Jackie age 19, Patricia age 4, Mary age 16 and an infant Jimmy. Now that the family head is unable to provide or care for this large family, the admission of the three school age children would relieve the mother of a considerable burden. In addition the small dwelling in which they live is inadequate for their number. Although the eldest son will be able to provide a little assistance, for the most part this family will be entirely dependent on this office.

While the admission of these children Anna, Michael and Andrew would be most beneficial in many ways the cost of their fares from Atlin to Lejac would be considerable, approximately $350.00. There is also the possibility that the proposed school at Lower Post may be completed this fall and that their admission theremight be more practical. In the event the Department may authorize this expenditure, Father Arsenault, O.M.I., Atlin, has written to the Principal of Lejac enquiring about possible accommodation for these children.

May this office be advised if the Department will approve this application?

Replying to your letter of October 27, 1951, regarding the admission of several pupils from the Stony Creek Reserve to the Lejac Residential School. I have to advise that owing to the fact we could not obtain the services of a teacher, the Stony Creek Day School is closed. Under these circumstances, the pupils in question were admitted to the Residential School.

Major Davey advised recently that he has located a teacher and the Stony Creek School will be re-opened in about two weeks time. In this event the pupils referred to will be discharged from the Lejac Residential School, following the Xmas Holidays, if not sooner.

November 9, 1951.

Attached please find two accounts covering the transportation of Indian pupils from the Fort Ware and Fort Grahame Reserves to the Lejac Indian Residential School.

It is realized that the payment of these accounts is contrary to the general policy of the Department with respect to the payment of transportation costs for children returning to schools. I do feel, however, that in this particular case an exception might be made. The economy among our native people in this northern section of British Columbia is not comparable to the rest of the province and in addition the cost of transportation, where planes and boats must be specially chartered for these trips, makes the cost to the parents prohibitive.

It is recommended that special consideration be given to this request and that the Department approve the payment of these accounts.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Mileage Voucher No. 435, April 1952.
Wm. Lee Cochran, Fort St. James, B.C.

I wish to refer to your letter of May 19th, 1952, advising that the Department has deleted $21.96 from the above Voucher, charged for conveying school children from Fort St. James, B.C., to the Lejac Residential School, a distance of "156" miles.

Mr. Cochran was authorised by myself to make this trip to convey the Moise children to Lejac. The mother of these children suffered a hemorrhage and was admitted as an emergency case to the Miller Bay Hospital.

Foster care could not be found for these children. Therefore, it was necessary to take them to Lejac School immediately by car. No other means of transportation was available at the time and under my instructions, Mr. Cochran transported the children to Lejac.

In view of the foregoing, I trust the Department will remit the amount of $21.96 in payment for this trip.

R. Howe,
Indian Superintendent.

I have your letter of May 16th, 1952, concerning the admission of the John children of the Stony Creek Band, and the Moise children from the Necoslie Band to the Lejac Indian Residential School.

The father of the John children was admitted to a mental hospital for prolonged treatment and the mother neglected the children in a shameful manner, it was therefore considered advisable to place them in Lejac School.

The mother of the Moise children was admitted to Miller Bay Hospital for prolonged treatment for tuberculosis and foster homes could not be found at Fort St. James. Therefore there was no alternative, but to admit them to the Lejac Residential School.

Dear Mr. Phalen: RE: Circular dated July 23/52.

I have given careful consideration to the above circular regarding the admission of pupils into the Residential School.

I am particularly concerned over this paragraph: "Before accepting any child in a residential school for the first time, the Principal must have the regular application and certificate of health completed, signed by the Indian Superintendent and approved by the Dept."

In this country of vast distances and difficult communications this paragraph is hard to follow to the letter. To give a specific instance,

A group of children were brought by their parents to Fort McLeod. They had travelled four days and five nights by way of the Findlay and Parsnip Rivers. They were met by car at Fort McLeod and transported 195 miles to this school. Among them were some new pupils and the application forms were signed by the parents when they parted from them at Fort McLeod.

In bringing such to the school it would seem that the above paragraph is not being carried out. As I would interpret it a doctor would have to go to Fort McLeod, examine the children, fill the report and send same to the Superintendent who would then forward it to Ottawa. Only on its return could the children be brought to the school. What is to be done with them in the meantime? If they return with their parents over the four day and five night trip they will not be seen again until next Spring. Thus a year of school is wasted and probably by next Spring they would need another physical examination before being admitted. In practise they were brought here to the school to await the doctors examination and the admission papers are now being completed for forwarding to Ottawa.

Today two children arrived unannounced via C.N.R. from Grassy Plains. No doctor's examination,
Lejac Indian Residential School
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers
Lejac, B.C.

no admission papers, just boy and girl. Their parents travelled a considerable distance to reach the railway station and no doubt by now are on their way back. Should we put the children on the next train and return them taking the chance that they may miss their parents and so be stranded? What better can we do than accept them await the doctors examination and prepare the admission papers to be signed when the parents are contacted. That may take from one week to a month.

The circular states that no grant can be claimed for such children until admission papers have been approved by Ottawa. This seems to be a severe penalty on the school for trying to act in the best interests of the children.

If the parents could be educated to register their children six months or a year before the actual date of entrance the prescriptions of the circular could be observed. However that is going to entail quite an effort and I doubt if it is feasible with the Indians of this country.

We are preparing the admission forms to the best of our ability and forwarding them to Ottawa as soon as it is feasible. I trust that you will appreciate our difficulty and allow grant for the month of September for those accepted.

Sincerely Yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I., Principal.

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Lejac Indian Residential School, we do not appear to have received applications for admission for pupils 0671-0675, 0677, 0678 and 0683 consequently their admission to the Lejac School has not been approved. In view of this fact we are disallowing the per capita grant claimed for them on the September Return.

It would be appreciated if you would arrange to secure these applications and forward them to this office for consideration. When the admissions are approved, you will be advised accordingly and the Principal may then claim retroactive grant for these children on the December Quarterly Return.

As pupils # 522 and 0656 were in residence during June, the school is entitled to 62 days grant for the months of July and August for them. We are consequently allowing this amount on the Return.

As pupil # C584 was not in residence during June, we are therefore, disallowing the 62 days claimed for her on the September Return. We are allowing the 30 days for September.

During the summer and early fall this office started a campaign to publicise the Lejac Indian Residential School amongst the Fort Babine and Old Fort Bands with a view of having some of the children enrolled at this school. Over the years and after a few unfortunate accidents at the school these Indian parents reached a state of mind where they would not let their children attend Lejac as they thought the child would either die there or return home sick. This I know was not correct and after much propaganda and persuasion four families volunteered to send their children. I hope they will be favourably impressed so that next year I might admit other needy cases without too much trouble.

Applications for admission are, in this case, being forwarded after the children are in school as it was not known until the last minute whether any of these children would attend. Once they made up their minds and reached the school Rev. Fr. Kelly took them in immediately less there should be a change of mind while waiting for Departmental approval.

The admissions are as follows:

1. Magdalene WEST - The father operates a logging camp where the children would receive no schooling.
2. Doris WEST
3. Catherine ABRAHAM
4. Frances Susan ABRAHAM
5. Cecile ABRAHAM
6. Mildred WILLIAMS - Member of Old Fort but lives on Chelslata Reserve. No school on either reserve.
Mother deceased and father believed to be in vicinity of Burns Lake, B.C. Children have been very unsettled being cared for by various relatives.

M. G. JUTAS
Indian Superintendent

Ottawa, December 15, 1937.

Dear Father Grant:

In response to the request contained in your letter of the 4th instant, I am sending forward, under separate cover, 20 follow-up report forms.

It is my intention to visit the province of British Columbia some time in the future. I am not at all sure, however, that I shall be in a position to make the trip next year.

I heartily agree with you when you express the view that handicraft projects should be promoted at our Indian residential schools. I have been emphasizing the necessity for vocational instruction and handicraft work during the last year, and it is encouraging to learn from reports that have reached us that the majority of our Indian day and residential schools have now made provision for vocational instruction.

I feel confident Inspector Barry and Commissioner MacKay can, with the experience they have had, provide you with a number of helpful suggestions. Both these men are in close contact with conditions on the reserves and are really in a better position to give you worth-while advice than I am. The reports that have reached me since you became Principal at Lejac have been very encouraging. I feel confident you are doing a good work at the institution.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. W. Byrne Grant, O.M.I.,

LEJAC, B.C.

December 4th, 1937

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Would you please be kind enough to send us twenty more copies of Follow-up Report on Residential School Graduate.

The Commissioner, Major McKay, was here recently and tells me that there is a very good prospect of your making a visit of the schools of the West early next year. I hope that you will not allow the apparent inaccessibility of Lejac and the rather hard reputation that our Northern winter seems to have in the East, to prevent you from paying us a visit and in preparing your schedule I hope you will keep in mind that there are only three trains a week so we will count on your staying a full two days.

When you do come I shall be specially anxious to discuss with you the question of handicrafts for the Indians leaving the school.

After a years residence here I have come to the conclusion that handicrafts which could be carried on and developed in the camps offer the best solution for the present poverty and thriftlessness of the Indians. Trapping seems to be disappearing fast, game is getting less abundant, the market for farm produce in the vicinity of the camps is limited and the indolence of the Indians makes it difficult for them to produce either a sufficient quantity or a regular supply for outside markets.

No doubt you have a bird's-eye view of this question as it affects all the Indians of Canada and will therefore be in a position to give us some practical advice.

We shall all be greatly disappointed if your expected visit does not materialize.

Yours very sincerely,

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending September 30th, 1939.

Attendance.
At present we have 178 children in the house, and two have been sent to the hospital, making 180 in all. There was very little difficulty experienced in bringing the children back to the school this term. In fact, we have been compelled to refuse admittance to some, because we could not afford to take them since our grant only allows for 160. There are still a few of the older pupils who have not yet been able to return, and for whom we will have to make room.

Morale.
The children are all in excellent spirits, and are quite happy to be back at school. There does not seem to be any inclination towards running away, as is usual at this time of the year.

Manual Training.
The piggery which the boys have built is nearing completion; and is a concrete example of what our Indian boys can do under proper example and instruction. The routine work of the carpenter shop and the farm work is going on in a satisfactory manner.

The girls are again working at their usual household tasks, as well as in spinning, carding, dressmaking, etc.

Health.
Most of the children are in good health, though many are in need of dental attention. Two children were sent to the hospital; one girl, who died of endocarditis, and a boy with pneumonia.

We were disappointed in not being able to get the services of the provincial T.B. clinic for the children when it passed through this district. The medical authorities of the Department seem to be very apathetic about the whole thing, despite the fact that such a step was originally suggested by Dr. McQuarrie when he was here last year.

Crops.
The yield was fairly good this year, though we do not know yet just what the potato crop will be. The garden was very successful and a large quantity of vegetables was put away for use later in the year.

Livestock.
All of our stock are in good condition, and their numbers are substantially the same as they were when the previous report was sent in; so there is no point in repeating them here.

In view of the rising prices of meat, our herd of pure bred Herefords promises to be a valuable investment.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Sir:

Re: Your Order #165.

The above order is for an assortment of mouldings and some Fir finish. Goods have gone forward to destination today and invoice to Mr. A.H. Simpson, Lejac, B.C.

In our quotation we quoted you on cedar finish as this together with Hemlock & Spruce is the species of lumber that we cut. Ottawa, February 6th, 1941.

Rev. Sirs:

I have your requisition of the 10th of December before me. The Department is anxious to encourage vocational education as much as circumstances will permit. The Department is also anxious to obtain as much education from the materials furnished as is possible.

On examining the above mentioned requisition, a few items have struck my attention. I would like to refer you to the Yankee drill point sets. The requisition calls for six additional sets. Our records indicate that three sets were sent out last February. This seems excessive to me. I would also call your attention to the oil stones. Our records indicate that in the last three or four years eight oil stones have been furnished. A check of these items would be appreciated.

Would not the carpenters' aprons be a good sewing project for the girls?

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
